body.head: Community building en France -- la suite
body.p: Days two and three of the Ecole Thematique I attended in Frejus last week (regrettably I had to leave on day four, thus missing the afternoon excursion to the seaside) were rich with matter. Each day began at nine sharp with a "state of the art" plenary presentation, which was followed by parallel sessions focussing on one of the three kinds of media in question -- manuscript materials, oral texts, or images. Although there was a natural tendency for each expert speaker to make their presentation fairly "one way", and in some cases also over-ran their allotted time rather drastically, there was a conscientious effort to provoke debate and discussion from the floor. A reasonably long lunch hour (and some excellent French food) also kept morale high and engaged. At the end of the day, participants summarized briefly the chief points of the communications they had witnessed; this seemed an idea worth stealing. (It would also be nice, but less practical, to steal the chef and the kitchen)

The wiki of the Ecole includes all the presentations, so I won't try to summarize them here, other than to note the range of topics addressed. In the plenaries, Christophe Jacobs was provocative on the "vulgarisation" facilitated by digital resources and its implications for modes of teaching and research while Catherine Morel was exhaustive and authoritative on the varieties of XML metadata. In the first session on written materials I attended, Paul Bertrand (IRHT) and Florence Clavaud (Ecole des Chartes) introduced us to the theory and practice of their digital cartulary (cartulR) in some detail. TELMA is both their collaboration and an open source "plateforme" for TEI corpora they are are jointly developing; they seem to be relying chiefly however on an EAD-based cataloguing system called Pleiade. There was some discussion about the problems they had encountered using Exist to handle large scale textual resources, and whether or not to switch over to using Philologic; and more about familiar problems of data entry. After lunch (rack of lamb; did I mention the food already?) I went to the first session on visual material and learned about a wonderful digital archive containing images of Lamarck's original specimen collection, and the complete papers of Ampere (currently being painstakingly transcribed by retired EDF functionaries), but was chiefly treated to a demonstration by Robert Vergnieux of some applications of GIS in classical archaeology notably a virtual Circus Maximus. For the third workshop session of the day, I returned to the text course for a decidedly pragmatic presentation from Thierry from the webmaster's perspective: how should resource builders ensure their labours are citeable, what standards are relevant, etc.

On the second day I attended an excellent workshop session from the CRDO's Michel Jacobson, giving just enough detail about the relevant standards in the world of metadata for spoken rsources (DCMI, OLAC, IMDI, etc.) for me to feel that this time I really do understand how OAI-PMH works and how to interface it with a bunch of TEI headers. No, really. His colleague Richard Walters gave a similarly thorough overview of the technical and theoretical issues involved in making and deploying transcriptions of oral materials: I wrote down as a usefully quotable comment his statement on the thornier theoretical issues: "I have no opinion but I want consistency".

After lunch on day two, we had brief introductions to some basic questions about the notion of interoperability, and to XML and friends. These were a little too short to cover everything, and soon ran out of time. There was a French take on that old favourite "how to make a TEI document with Oxygen and Roma", which was a lot of fun, not only for me but also for the participants, who all seemed to enjoy the experience of getting their hands dirty with some real tagging at last. (The session I attended was also enlivened by some accidental damage to the curtain rails by an over-excited Paul Bertrand). Those attending the practical session on using Pleiade which went on in parallel didn't seem to be having as much fun, but maybe I'm biassed. At the end of the day Michel Jacobsen gave a magisterial overview of what OAIS is, and how they are using it in the CRDO. This also managed to hold my attention.

I'm not sure how to translate "ecole thematique": "special-interest summer-school" doesn't quite do it justice. But in any case, this was clearly a new experience for many of those participating, not just for me. The organisers had done their best to escape from traditional French pedagogic models, and to bring into being a new kind of interdisciplinary context appropriate to the very diverse resources concerned. They also worked hard at ensuring we were not sold short on their varied technical expertise -- no sign of any vulgarisation there. Of course, some things didn't work as well as they might have (the timetabling was occasionally chaotic for example, and I think people might have enjoyed more practical work than it permitted); but this was an excellent experiment which I hope the organisers will be encouraged to repeat in a year or two. In the meantime. it will be very interesting to see how the wiki develops...
